4. TRACKING TECHNOLOGIES

Vertigo or its third parties may use tracking technologies, such as cookies and Web Beacons, to collect information about users who visit or use the Services and view or interact with Advertisements, Content, and Promotions.

Cookies.Vertigo uses cookies to help you access and navigate the Services more efficiently and to statistically monitor how many people are using a Service.

a. A cookie is a small file or tool stored on your computer or device containing information that allows Vertigo to deliver customized information to you. Vertigo uses both session and persistent cookies on the Services. Session cookies are temporary bits of information that are erased once you exit your web browser or turn off your computer or device. Persistent cookies are more permanent bits of information that are placed on the hard drive (or other storage media) of your computer or device and stay there unless you delete the cookie. Persistent cookies store information on your computer or device for a number of reasons, such as retrieving certain information you have previously provided (i.e., username and password), helping to determine what areas of a Service you find most valuable and customizing such Service based on your preferences on an ongoing basis.

b. You may set your browser to notify you of or decline the receipt of cookies. Certain features of a Service, including certain Content, or Promotions, may not, however, function properly or be available if your browser is configured to disable cookies. Many companies offer programs that help you to visit websites or mobile versions of such sites anonymously. While Vertigo will not be able to provide you with a personalized experience if Vertigo cannot recognize you, Vertigo wants you to be aware that these programs are available.

Web Beacons.During your use of a Service, you may encounter Web Beacons, which may come from Vertigo or from third parties that display or provide Advertisements, Content, or Promotions or services on such Service.

a. A Web Beacon (sometimes also called a web bug or clear gif) is a small graphic image in a web page, a web-based document or an e-mail message that generally allows the party that set the Web Beacon to monitor certain information about the viewer of the web page, web-based document or e-mail message and may allow access to certain cookies. Web Beacons are usually invisible to the user because they are very small (generally 1-by-1 pixel). In general, however, any electronic image viewed as part of a web page, including an Advertisement or Content, can act as a Web Beacon.

b. Web Beacons on the website typically collect the URL of the page from which the Web Beacon originates, the type of browser requesting the Web Beacon, the IP address of the computer or device ID of the device to which the Web Beacon is sent and the time that the Web Beacon was viewed.

c. Certain Web Beacons used by third party advertisers, content providers or other service providers may collect information that allows such third parties to determine how many people are viewing and/or clicking on certain Advertisements or viewing certain Content, Promotions or Services for purposes of helping these parties serve and manage their Advertisements, Content, Promotions and Services. These Web Beacons do not collect or store Personal Information but they may, however, be used in conjunction with cookies to identify certain aggregate information about users.

Most content in quest zombie genre

The bad: this has the textures and resolution that you should expect from a quest game. It also crashed occasionally for me. Some checkpoint placement is off and means deaths mean 20 or 30 minutes of catch up play. Two handed weapons are tricky to handle, lining up the front and back sights is very finicky. Grenades throw poorly. There's no melee.

The good: the shooting has absolutely been nailed here. Pistols are excellent and feel realistic, you have to really take care to aim. The atmosphere is fantastic - from sun bleached outdoors to flashlight illuminated mineshafts. You actually feel a sense of progression in the story like a traditional game. There's a variety too, between exploring with few enemies, to being rushed by waves and waves. There's co-op here too, though sadly it's not cross platform. There is far, far more content in this game than its competitors (other reviews compare this game and usually leave this fact out). To me it justifies the price. I'd go so far as to say if you like survival horror, zombies and guns, you'll like this game.

eoinokMar 6 at 3:46 PM
Flawed but kind of brilliant

I really enjoyed this game. But for me it's less than 5 stars for the following reasons:

1. Bizarre interaction mechanics. I'll be brief and give just one example: you can't drop a weapon. It sticks to your hand. When you want to use that hand to, say, turn a door handle, the weapon simply snaps out of existence and then reappears after. I can kind of see why the developers might have thought this was convenient. For me it was very counterintuitive and immersion-breaking.

2. Invisible barriers. I understand that there have to be limits on where the player can go, and obstacles that must be overcome through puzzle-solving are a staple of great games. However, this game makes the conceit obvious to the point that it took me right out of the experience. You constantly encounter barriers that look for all the world like they could easily be walked around, over, under, or straight through, only to hear your character exclaim that they're utterly impassable until some key or whatever has been located. Barriers are fine, but they should look at least somewhat plausible as barriers. The situation isn't helped by the fact that some zombies *are* able to climb over barriers that our hero needs a key to get past.

That said, this is a relatively open, long, free-roaming experience with a real sense of journeying across great distances, through fairly varied environments. That's rare for Quest games and very rare for shooters. The story is compelling, the voice acting is solid and the set pieces are among the best I've experienced. You feel like you've been through something when you get to the end. The best compliment I can give is that upon finishing it I went right back and played it again from the start.

Update: They added the ability to drop weapons. However, the implementation is - sorry to use this word again - bizarre. Rather than releasing the grip button to, you know, release an object from your grip, you have to hold A until a circle fills up. What's worse is that instructions pop up showing you how to this *repeatedly* during gameplay. And the way these instructions work is that your weapon is replaced by a model of the controller. Again, this happens *frequently* while you're playing. Talk about immersion-breaking. Still, at least you can drop weapons now. As a further update, I'm still replaying and loving this game. There is a fantastic core experience to be enjoyed here. Don't just give up on it. Keep going. It gets really good, despite the flaws!

3. Why do you never interact with NPCs? You spend the entire game trying to get to civilization, and unless you are playing with a friend you never get to see anyone! This along with some other nit picky things (like people wearing a swimsuit or a motorcycle helmet inside of an army base) can bug people, but many people dont mind at all.

Slow, but enjoyable

Pros:
Story oriented - this game is by and far more of an adventure game with zombies than a true shooter. The story is compelling enough, though it is just thinly veiled excuses connecting set piece locations together, but the protagonist is entertaining to listen to and you're really here you enjoy the journey rather than blast zombies.

Cons:
Bad pacing - The game is slow, like really really slow most of the time, the majority of zombies you encounter are not a threat and come in ones and twos. You will spend most of your play time walking through corridors looking for macguffins to unlock doors. The action parts of the game swing the pendulum right the other way, usually at the climax of each area.

Janky gunplay - I can see the devs where probably going for realism here, but aiming is pretty difficult. On top of the usual issues aiming guns in vr present, there's also an aiming cone the bullets trajectory is randomly fired down. This makes long range head shots pretty much impossible, forcing you to get really close. mind you, this doesn't actually make the zombies any more dangerous, just frustrating during the action sections.

Overall:
The game has a lot of hype, and thus did not meet my expectations in any way.

It's competent, and enjoyable, but there are far better zombie shooters for far cheaper.

I'd recommend if it where on sale, but it's definitely not worth the exorbitant price tag, and don't be fooled, this game is about the journey, not the action.

RandomMan85Feb 7 at 3:01 PM
Sunshine Left 4 Dead?

Ok, so I had my eye on this game for a while as I love nothing more than blasting zombies, but it took me a while to pull the trigger (pun intended) due to the high price. 30 for a game which some people claim can be completed in 2 hours? It just didn't sit right with me. Anyway, out of the blue a wild sale appears! The game was reduced to 22.99. Ok, that seemed a bit more reasonable so I finally purchased the game.

Over the course of the next few days I played the game solid and in two sessions I made my way through sunny Arizona to the end of the game. The experience lasted me around 5 hours in total because I like to explore everything in video games. The game itself is probably one of my favourite experiences on the Quest so far and one of the few that I have been driven to complete in back to back sessions. So what compelled me to finish the game?

First of all I must say that the graphics are OK. Far from the quality of some other Quest titles, but they are enough to breath some life into the land of the undead, and although it's great to have sparkly, pretty graphics it is always worth remembering that the quest is essentially running on the hardware of last years mobile phones. So in my eyes the main thing I look for in a Quest game is how satisfying the gameplay is and this is where Arizona Sunshine, well.....shines...
The gunplay is very good and shooting the heads off zombies is extremely satisfying! You have to really line up those sights before you are rewarded with a gruesome POP! Depending on which part of the head you shoot also determines how the head explodes too. I mean, you can literally shoot a zombie's face off!
The exploration in AS is good too and although it's a linear experience the levels are big enough to provide a sense of exploration and immersion. However, the puzzles are really simple and never evolve much beyond find the key or the crank handle etc... although shooting zombies is what this game is truly about and it does this very well, with a multitude of weapons to choose from, ranging from pistols to grenade launchers.

So in conclusion is it worth the asking price? I would say yes and no. At 30 it's a tough decision although there is always horde mode to mess about with after the credits role and if you really fancy a challenge there is Apocalyptic mode which is said to be extremely hard to beat (I haven't got round to that yet). So if you like the main gameplay you could squeeze some extra zombie juice out of the title, and of course there is upcoming DLC which promises to extend the main campaign further.

All in all I had a blast and I don't regret my purchase at all, although I will deduct a point for the high price tag.

You play as a guy who makes snarky remarks and witty puns. His goal is to escape the zombies which he refers to as Fred. He always says the goal out loud. Locked door? "Gotta find the key." No power? Fun, but Rough Around the Edges.

Let's start off by saying Arizona Sunshine is always going to be one of those classic VR titles that everyone should play at least once. Here's the good before we get into the roughness. Shooting the zombies is great fun. Some of the vistas and locations were highly immersive and beautiful to look at. It's quite the adventure, and there's so much to be said for mowing down a horde of zombies in the beautiful Arizona desert. You can sympathize with the main character as he searches for survivors, and the game makes you feel like you are the main character. That being said, let's get into why I'm giving it three stars. It's not the graphical quality, which I actually disregard most of the time when making reviews. I didn't mind the graphics at all, when they worked. On Quest, there's an extreme level of pop-in inside certain levels of the campaign. The abandoned mine for instance, was broken for me; I could see through the walls into blank whiteness as I walked through it. Almost none of the environment was showing up. It didn't just break the immersion, it almost broke the game. When I used the radio above the hillbilly park, the whole game glitched out, and I had to reboot and try again, then it worked. In the end I was still able to get through the game. When it was working smoothly, I had the time of my life. The Horde Mode Multiplayer has an issue with finding matches as far as I can tell. When someone did finally show up, it was an amazing experience. I hope multiplayer is more populated than I think it is, because it's so much fun! In conclusion, this is a really early VR game, and has earned it's place among the classics, but there needs to be some remastering. I don't regret my purchase, I enjoyed it. Thumbs up.

The campaign isnt short, so Ill give them that, but the puzzles and gameplay arent anything special, and the voice acting is atrocious. I initially wanted the game for the replay-ability of the horde mode. Wave after wave of killing zombies sounds fun, and it is for a while, but theres only so much you can do. Its just shooting zombies, eating a hamburger patty, reloading, and repeating. Almost everyone you will meet is about 10. The object physics are pretty broken- certain objects will float in place, and the object positions arent the same between online players, which really shatters the scarce amount of immersion that this game provides. I was also annoyed by the lack of animations for other players- they dont walk, they glide, and their legs slide around after them, like theyre glued to the ground. While its not game breaking, youd think a forty dollar game would do better. I think that this games only redeeming quality is that you can play the campaign with a friend. If you really want to play an online wave-based zombie shooting game, set up Sidequest, and download Pavlov Shack. Its free at the moment, and has a zombies mode which is better all around. If you were interested in the campaign, I recommend waiting for the quest release of TWD- Saints and Sinners, which looks to be much better in respects to story, atmosphere, physics, and (probably) price. I cant decide if you buy this game or not, but all I can ask is that you be smart with your money.

SaxomophonistFeb 1 at 8:56 AM
Pros & Cons

First off, I have played this game quite a lot now and feel I can finally share my opinion on it, but it is just MY opinion.
Like the game if you choose, as despite my feelings about it, I have to acknowledge that there aren't too many multiplayer shooters on the Quest, so this game was a welcome addition for the community.


Pros:
- Multiplayer Mode (Horde Mode)
- Coop Campaign Mode
- Simplistic gun mechanics (appeals to more ppl)
- Good weapon variety
- Wearable masks to be found in-game
- Zombie dismemberment and the level of gore is quite satisfying
- Zombie appearances are varied, with differing armour types as well


Cons:
- Two handed weapons don't respond well at all to the grip system
- Aiming doesn't feel intuitive or natural (maybe allow alignment changes in the settings)
- Tossing grenades is sad and underwhelming (adjust the in-game physics)
- Weapons only have the one firing mode (having the option to change this on the fly would be incredibly satisfying)
- Character customisation is almost non-existent and even the masks are constantly clipping/phasing through players' heads (provide just a few different default skins for multiplayer mode even. Maybe in future, more skins could be unlocked through event completion)
- Unable to discard unwanted weapons (should be able to throw away the weapons you no longer need or that you accidentally pick up)
- No melee combat (even Pavlov has a shove mechanic. That's all we need I guess, but melee weapons would be ideal)
- Zombie types are way too simplistic. They either run, walk or crawl... take something from all the other successful zombie games and give us more types (such as belchers, screamers, juggernauts, etc.)
- $50AUD/$35USD for a short campaign with little replayability and 3 multiplayer maps is not worth it (I finished the campaign on the hardest difficulty quite quickly and with ease. Add more to the campaign to make it enticing to replay or at least an additional Hardcore difficulty setting)
- Graphics are not optimised as well as I'd like. While I appreciate that the DEVs definitely optimised a lot and did a tonne of work redesigning a large portion of the game, I still feel like everything is blurry and aiming at range feels uncomfortable at best. Right from their opening logos, everything just loses that crispness evident in so many other games (Drop Dead/Death Horizon/Pavlov all do a better job in this regard)

Fun coop gameplay not just horde modes, there isn't anything coop out like this.

Coming into this game I didn't expect a ton graphically considering the Quest's hardware constraints - and the developer did deliver what I had set my expectations to which was a more blocky, lackluster appearance on everything. If you can get over the graphics, however, the game is excellent. I had no issues with controls as I did not use the teleport controls and went with the smooth walking ones, I also changed the turning to smooth. The mechanics in the game are great, aiming is nice and feels natural and reloading is a breeze. Interactive objects are everywhere, including hamburger patties to chow down on and car doors/trunks to open everywhere. Mechanics for opening doors, be it car or building, are great and give you a real good feel overall.
